title: The Future of Startup Funding
title_zh: [待翻译] The Future of Startup Funding

paragraphs: Want to start a startup? Get funded by Y Combinator. August 2010Two years ago I wrote about what I called "a huge, unexploited opportunity in startup funding:" the growing disconnect between VCs, whose current business model requires them to invest large amounts, and a large class of startups that need less than they used to.

Increasingly, startups want a couple hundred thousand dollars, not a couple million. [1]The opportunity is a lot less unexploited now. Investors have poured into this territory from both directions. VCs are much more likely to make angel-sized investments than they were a year ago.

And meanwhile the past year has seen a dramatic increase in a new type of investor: the super-angel, who operates like an angel, but using other people's money, like a VC.Though a lot of investors are entering this territory, there is still room for more.

The distribution of investors should mirror the distribution of startups, which has the usual power law dropoff. So there should be a lot more people investing tens or hundreds of thousands than millions.

[2]In fact, it may be good for angels that there are more people doing angel-sized deals, because if angel rounds become more legitimate, then startups may start to opt for angel rounds even when they could, if they wanted, raise series A rounds from VCs.

One reason startups prefer series A rounds is that they're more prestigious. But if angel investors become more active and better known, they'll increasingly be able to compete with VCs in brand.Of course, prestige isn't the main reason to prefer a series A round.

A startup will probably get more attention from investors in a series A round than an angel round. So if a startup is choosing between an angel round and an A round from a good VC fund, I usually advise them to take the A round.

[3]But while series A rounds aren't going away, I think VCs should be more worried about super-angels than vice versa. Despite their name, the super-angels are really mini VC funds, and they clearly have existing VCs in their sights.They would seem to have history on their side.

The pattern here seems the same one we see when startups and established companies enter a new market. Online video becomes possible, and YouTube plunges right in, while existing media companies embrace it only half-willingly, driven more by fear than hope, and aiming more to protect their turf than to do great things for users.

Ditto for PayPal. This pattern is repeated over and over, and it's usually the invaders who win. In this case the super-angels are the invaders. Angel rounds are their whole business, as online video was for YouTube.

Whereas VCs who make angel investments mostly do it as a way to generate deal flow for series A rounds. [4]On the other hand, startup investing is a very strange business. Nearly all the returns are concentrated in a few big winners.

If the super-angels merely fail to invest in (and to some extent produce) the big winners, they'll be out of business, even if they invest in all the others.VCsWhy don't VCs start doing smaller series A rounds?

The sticking point is board seats. In a traditional series A round, the partner whose deal it is takes a seat on the startup's board. If we assume the average startup runs for 6 years and a partner can bear to be on 12 boards at once, then a VC fund can do 2 series A deals per partner per year.It has always seemed to me the solution is to take fewer board seats.

You don't have to be on the board to help a startup. Maybe VCs feel they need the power that comes with board membership to ensure their money isn't wasted. But have they tested that theory? Unless they've tried not taking board seats and found their returns are lower, they're not bracketing the problem.I'm not saying VCs don't help startups.

The good ones help them a lot. What I'm saying is that the kind of help that matters, you may not have to be a board member to give. [5]How will this all play out? Some VCs will probably adapt, by doing more, smaller deals.

I wouldn't be surprised if by streamlining their selection process and taking fewer board seats, VC funds could do 2 to 3 times as many series A rounds with no loss of quality.But other VCs will make no more than superficial changes.

VCs are conservative, and the threat to them isn't mortal. The VC funds that don't adapt won't be violently displaced. They'll edge gradually into a different business without realizing it. They'll still do what they will call series A rounds, but these will increasingly be de facto series B rounds.

[6]In such rounds they won't get the 25 to 40% of the company they do now. You don't give up as much of the company in later rounds unless something is seriously wrong. Since the VCs who don't adapt will be investing later, their returns from winners may be smaller.

But investing later should also mean they have fewer losers. So their ratio of risk to return may be the same or even better. They'll just have become a different, more conservative, type of investment.AngelsIn the big angel rounds that increasingly compete with series A rounds, the investors won't take as much equity as VCs do now.

And VCs who try to compete with angels by doing more, smaller deals will probably find they have to take less equity to do it. Which is good news for founders: they'll get to keep more of the company.The deal terms of angel rounds will become less restrictive too—not just less restrictive than series A terms, but less restrictive than angel terms have traditionally been.In the future, angel rounds will less often be for specific amounts or have a lead investor.

In the old days, the standard m.o. for startups was to find one angel to act as the lead investor. You'd negotiate a round size and valuation with the lead, who'd supply some but not all of the money.

Then the startup and the lead would cooperate to find the rest.The future of angel rounds looks more like this: instead of a fixed round size, startups will do a rolling close, where they take money from investors one at a time till they feel they have enough.

[7] And though there's going to be one investor who gives them the first check, and his or her help in recruiting other investors will certainly be welcome, this initial investor will no longer be the lead in the old sense of managing the round.

The startup will now do that themselves.There will continue to be lead investors in the sense of investors who take the lead in advising a startup. They may also make the biggest investment. But they won't always have to be the one terms are negotiated with, or be the first money in, as they have in the past.

Standardized paperwork will do away with the need to negotiate anything except the valuation, and that will get easier too.If multiple investors have to share a valuation, it will be whatever the startup can get from the first one to write a check, limited by their guess at whether this will make later investors balk.

But there may not have to be just one valuation. Startups are increasingly raising money on convertible notes, and convertible notes have not valuations but at most valuation caps: caps on what the effective valuation will be when the debt converts to equity (in a later round, or upon acquisition if that happens first).

That's an important difference because it means a startup could do multiple notes at once with different caps. This is now starting to happen, and I predict it will become more common.SheepThe reason things are moving this way is that the old way sucked for startups.

Leads could (and did) use a fixed size round as a legitimate-seeming way of saying what all founders hate to hear: I'll invest if other people will. Most investors, unable to judge startups for themselves, rely instead on the opinions of other investors.

If everyone wants in, they want in too; if not, not. Founders hate this because it's a recipe for deadlock, and delay is the thing a startup can least afford. Most investors know this m.o. is lame, and few say openly that they're doing it.

But the craftier ones achieve the same result by offering to lead rounds of fixed size and supplying only part of the money. If the startup can't raise the rest, the lead is out too. How could they go ahead with the deal?

The startup would be underfunded!In the future, investors will increasingly be unable to offer investment subject to contingencies like other people investing. Or rather, investors who do that will get last place in line.

Startups will go to them only to fill up rounds that are mostly subscribed. And since hot startups tend to have rounds that are oversubscribed, being last in line means they'll probably miss the hot deals.

Hot deals and successful startups are not identical, but there is a significant correlation. [8] So investors who won't invest unilaterally will have lower returns.Investors will probably find they do better when deprived of this crutch anyway.

Chasing hot deals doesn't make investors choose better; it just makes them feel better about their choices. I've seen feeding frenzies both form and fall apart many times, and as far as I can tell they're mostly random.

[9] If investors can no longer rely on their herd instincts, they'll have to think more about each startup before investing. They may be surprised how well this works.Deadlock wasn't the only disadvantage of letting a lead investor manage an angel round.

The investors would not infrequently collude to push down the valuation. And rounds took too long to close, because however motivated the lead was to get the round closed, he was not a tenth as motivated as the startup.Increasingly, startups are taking charge of their own angel rounds.

Only a few do so far, but I think we can already declare the old way dead, because those few are the best startups. They're the ones in a position to tell investors how the round is going to work. And if the startups you want to invest in do things a certain way, what difference does it make what the others do?TractionIn fact, it may be slightly misleading to say that angel rounds will increasingly take the place of series A rounds.

What's really happening is that startup-controlled rounds are taking the place of investor-controlled rounds.This is an instance of a very important meta-trend, one that Y Combinator itself has been based on from the beginning: founders are becoming increasingly powerful relative to investors.

So if you want to predict what the future of venture funding will be like, just ask: how would founders like it to be? One by one, all the things founders dislike about raising money are going to get eliminated.

[10]Using that heuristic, I'll predict a couple more things. One is that investors will increasingly be unable to wait for startups to have "traction" before they put in significant money. It's hard to predict in advance which startups will succeed.

So most investors prefer, if they can, to wait till the startup is already succeeding, then jump in quickly with an offer. Startups hate this as well, partly because it tends to create deadlock, and partly because it seems kind of slimy.

If you're a promising startup but don't yet have significant growth, all the investors are your friends in words, but few are in actions. They all say they love you, but they all wait to invest. Then when you start to see growth, they claim they were your friend all along, and are aghast at the thought you'd be so disloyal as to leave them out of your round.

If founders become more powerful, they'll be able to make investors give them more money upfront.(The worst variant of this behavior is the tranched deal, where the investor makes a small initial investment, with more to follow if the startup does well.

In effect, this structure gives the investor a free option on the next round, which they'll only take if it's worse for the startup than they could get in the open market. Tranched deals are an abuse.

They're increasingly rare, and they're going to get rarer.) [11]Investors don't like trying to predict which startups will succeed, but increasingly they'll have to. Though the way that happens won't necessarily be that the behavior of existing investors will change; it may instead be that they'll be replaced by other investors with different behavior—that investors who understand startups well enough to take on the hard problem of predicting their trajectory will tend to displace suits whose skills lie more in raising money from LPs.SpeedThe other thing founders hate most about fundraising is how long it takes.

So as founders become more powerful, rounds should start to close faster.Fundraising is still terribly distracting for startups. If you're a founder in the middle of raising a round, the round is the top idea in your mind, which means working on the company isn't.

If a round takes 2 months to close, which is reasonably fast by present standards, that means 2 months during which the company is basically treading water. That's the worst thing a startup could do.So if investors want to get the best deals, the way to do it will be to close faster.

Investors don't need weeks to make up their minds anyway. We decide based on about 10 minutes of reading an application plus 10 minutes of in person interview, and we only regret about 10% of our decisions.

If we can decide in 20 minutes, surely the next round of investors can decide in a couple days. [12]There are a lot of institutionalized delays in startup funding: the multi-week mating dance with investors; the distinction between termsheets and deals; the fact that each series A has enormously elaborate, custom paperwork.

Both founders and investors tend to take these for granted. It's the way things have always been. But ultimately the reason these delays exist is that they're to the advantage of investors. More time gives investors more information about a startup's trajectory, and it also tends to make startups more pliable in negotiations, since they're usually short of money.These conventions weren't designed to drag out the funding process, but that's why they're allowed to persist.

Slowness is to the advantage of investors, who have in the past been the ones with the most power. But there is no need for rounds to take months or even weeks to close, and once founders realize that, it's going to stop.

Not just in angel rounds, but in series A rounds too. The future is simple deals with standard terms, done quickly.One minor abuse that will get corrected in the process is option pools. In a traditional series A round, before the VCs invest they make the company set aside a block of stock for future hires—usually between 10 and 30% of the company.

The point is to ensure this dilution is borne by the existing shareholders. The practice isn't dishonest; founders know what's going on. But it makes deals unnecessarily complicated. In effect the valuation is 2 numbers.

There's no need to keep doing this. [13]The final thing founders want is to be able to sell some of their own stock in later rounds. This won't be a change, because the practice is now quite common. A lot of investors hated the idea, but the world hasn't exploded as a result, so it will happen more, and more openly.SurpriseI've talked here about a bunch of changes that will be forced on investors as founders become more powerful.

Now the good news: investors may actually make more money as a result.A couple days ago an interviewer asked me if founders having more power would be better or worse for the world. I was surprised, because I'd never considered that question.

Better or worse, it's happening. But after a second's reflection, the answer seemed obvious. Founders understand their companies better than investors, and it has to be better if the people with more knowledge have more power.One of the mistakes novice pilots make is overcontrolling the aircraft: applying corrections too vigorously, so the aircraft oscillates about the desired configuration instead of approaching it asymptotically.

It seems probable that investors have till now on average been overcontrolling their portfolio companies. In a lot of startups, the biggest source of stress for the founders is not competitors but investors.

Certainly it was for us at Viaweb. And this is not a new phenomenon: investors were James Watt's biggest problem too. If having less power prevents investors from overcontrolling startups, it should be better not just for founders but for investors too.Investors may end up with less stock per startup, but startups will probably do better with founders more in control, and there will almost certainly be more of them.

Investors all compete with one another for deals, but they aren't one another's main competitor. Our main competitor is employers. And so far that competitor is crushing us. Only a tiny fraction of people who could start a startup do.

Nearly all customers choose the competing product, a job. Why? Well, let's look at the product we're offering. An unbiased review would go something like this: Starting a startup gives you more freedom and the opportunity to make a lot more money than a job, but it's also hard work and at times very stressful.

Much of the stress comes from dealing with investors. If reforming the investment process removed that stress, we'd make our product much more attractive. The kind of people who make good startup founders don't mind dealing with technical problems—they enjoy technical problems—but they hate the type of problems investors cause.Investors have no idea that when they maltreat one startup, they're preventing 10 others from happening, but they are.

Indirectly, but they are. So when investors stop trying to squeeze a little more out of their existing deals, they'll find they're net ahead, because so many more new deals appear.One of our axioms at Y Combinator is not to think of deal flow as a zero-sum game.

Our main focus is to encourage more startups to happen, not to win a larger share of the existing stream. We've found this principle very useful, and we think as it spreads outward it will help later stage investors as well."Make something people want" applies to us too.Notes[1] In this essay I'm talking mainly about software startups.

These points don't apply to types of startups that are still expensive to start, e.g. in energy or biotech.Even the cheap kinds of startups will generally raise large amounts at some point, when they want to hire a lot of people.

What has changed is how much they can get done before that.[2] It's not the distribution of good startups that has a power law dropoff, but the distribution of potentially good startups, which is to say, good deals.

There are lots of potential winners, from which a few actual winners emerge with superlinear certainty.[3] As I was writing this, I asked some founders who'd taken series A rounds from top VC funds whether it was worth it, and they unanimously said yes.The quality of investor is more important than the type of round, though.

I'd take an angel round from good angels over a series A from a mediocre VC.[4] Founders also worry that taking an angel investment from a VC means they'll look bad if the VC declines to participate in the next round.

The trend of VC angel investing is so new that it's hard to say how justified this worry is.Another danger, pointed out by Mitch Kapor, is that if VCs are only doing angel deals to generate series A deal flow, then their incentives aren't aligned with the founders'.

The founders want the valuation of the next round to be high, and the VCs want it to be low. Again, hard to say yet how much of a problem this will be.[5] Josh Kopelman pointed out that another way to be on fewer boards at once is to take board seats for shorter periods.[6] Google was in this respect as so many others the pattern for the future.

It would be great for VCs if the similarity extended to returns. That's probably too much to hope for, but the returns may be somewhat higher, as I explain later.[7] Doing a rolling close doesn't mean the company is always raising money.

That would be a distraction. The point of a rolling close is to make fundraising take less time, not more. With a classic fixed sized round, you don't get any money till all the investors agree, and that often creates a situation where they all sit waiting for the others to act.

A rolling close usually prevents this. [8] There are two (non-exclusive) causes of hot deals: the quality of the company, and domino effects among investors. The former is obviously a better predictor of success.[9] Some of the randomness is concealed by the fact that investment is a self fulfilling prophecy.[10] The shift in power to founders is exaggerated now because it's a seller's market.

On the next downtick it will seem like I overstated the case. But on the next uptick after that, founders will seem more powerful than ever.[11] More generally, it will become less common for the same investor to invest in successive rounds, except when exercising an option to maintain their percentage.

When the same investor invests in successive rounds, it often means the startup isn't getting market price. They may not care; they may prefer to work with an investor they already know; but as the investment market becomes more efficient, it will become increasingly easy to get market price if they want it.

Which in turn means the investment community will tend to become more stratified.[12] The two 10 minuteses have 3 weeks between them so founders can get cheap plane tickets, but except for that they could be adjacent.[13] I'm not saying option pools themselves will go away.

They're an administrative convenience. What will go away is investors requiring them. Thanks to Sam Altman, John Bautista, Trevor Blackwell, Paul Buchheit, Jeff Clavier, Patrick Collison, Ron Conway, Matt Cohler, Chris Dixon, Mitch Kapor, Josh Kopelman, Pete Koomen, Carolynn Levy, Jessica Livingston, Ariel Poler, Geoff Ralston, Naval Ravikant, Dan Siroker, Harj Taggar, and Fred Wilson for reading drafts of this.

paragraphs.original: VCs are conservative, and the threat to them isn't mortal. The VC funds that don't adapt won't be violently displaced. They'll edge gradually into a different business without realizing it. They'll still do what they will call series A rounds, but these will increasingly be de facto series B rounds.
paragraphs.translated: 风险投资家们是保守的，他们面临的威胁并不致命。那些不适应变化的风险投资基金不会被剧烈淘汰。它们会不知不觉地逐渐转向不同的业务。它们仍然会进行所谓的A轮融资，但这些实际上会越来越多地变成实质上的B轮融资。

paragraphs.original: [6]In such rounds they won't get the 25 to 40% of the company they do now. You don't give up as much of the company in later rounds unless something is seriously wrong. Since the VCs who don't adapt will be investing later, their returns from winners may be smaller.
paragraphs.translated: 在这样的轮次中，他们不会像现在这样获得公司25%到40%的股份。除非公司出了严重问题，否则在后期轮次中不会放弃如此多的公司股份。由于不适应的风投将在后期进行投资，他们从成功项目中获得的回报可能会减少。

paragraphs.original: But investing later should also mean they have fewer losers. So their ratio of risk to return may be the same or even better. They'll just have become a different, more conservative, type of investment.AngelsIn the big angel rounds that increasingly compete with series A rounds, the investors won't take as much equity as VCs do now.
paragraphs.translated: 但后来投资也应该意味着他们会有更少的失败者。因此，他们的风险与回报比率可能相同，甚至更好。他们只是会变成一种不同类型的，更加保守的投资。在那些越来越与A轮融资竞争的大天使轮中，投资者不会像现在的风险投资公司那样获取那么多的股权。

paragraphs.original: And VCs who try to compete with angels by doing more, smaller deals will probably find they have to take less equity to do it. Which is good news for founders: they'll get to keep more of the company.The deal terms of angel rounds will become less restrictive too—not just less restrictive than series A terms, but less restrictive than angel terms have traditionally been.In the future, angel rounds will less often be for specific amounts or have a lead investor.
paragraphs.translated: 而试图通过做更多小型交易与天使投资者竞争的风险资本家可能会发现，他们必须接受更少的股权才能实现这一目标。这对创始人来说是个好消息：他们将能够保留公司更多的股份。天使轮融资的条款也将变得更加宽松——不仅比A轮融资的条款宽松，甚至比传统的天使投资条款更加宽松。未来，天使轮融资将更少地限定为特定金额或有领投投资者。

paragraphs.original: In the old days, the standard m.o. for startups was to find one angel to act as the lead investor. You'd negotiate a round size and valuation with the lead, who'd supply some but not all of the money.
paragraphs.translated: 过去，创业公司的标准做法是找到一位天使投资人作为领投人。你会与这位领投人协商融资规模和估值，领投人会提供一部分但不是全部的资金。

paragraphs.original: Then the startup and the lead would cooperate to find the rest.The future of angel rounds looks more like this: instead of a fixed round size, startups will do a rolling close, where they take money from investors one at a time till they feel they have enough.
paragraphs.translated: 然后，初创公司和领投人将合作寻找其余投资者。天使轮融资的未来将更像这样：初创公司将不再设定固定的融资规模，而是进行滚动关闭，即一次从投资者那里募集资金，直到他们觉得自己已经筹集到了足够的资金。

paragraphs.original: [7] And though there's going to be one investor who gives them the first check, and his or her help in recruiting other investors will certainly be welcome, this initial investor will no longer be the lead in the old sense of managing the round.
paragraphs.translated: 而且，虽然会有一个投资者给他们开出第一张支票，这位投资者在招揽其他投资者方面的帮助当然会受到欢迎，但这位初始投资者将不再像过去那样担任牵头管理整个融资轮的角色。

paragraphs.original: The startup will now do that themselves.There will continue to be lead investors in the sense of investors who take the lead in advising a startup. They may also make the biggest investment. But they won't always have to be the one terms are negotiated with, or be the first money in, as they have in the past.
paragraphs.translated: 这家初创公司现在将自行处理这些事务。仍将有领投者，即在为初创公司提供建议方面发挥主导作用的投资者。他们也可能进行最大的投资。但不再必须由他们来协商条款，也不必总是他们首先投入资金，就像过去那样。

paragraphs.original: Standardized paperwork will do away with the need to negotiate anything except the valuation, and that will get easier too.If multiple investors have to share a valuation, it will be whatever the startup can get from the first one to write a check, limited by their guess at whether this will make later investors balk.
paragraphs.translated: 标准化的文件将消除除估值外的所有谈判需求，而估值的确定也将变得更加容易。如果多个投资者需要共享一个估值，那将取决于初创公司从第一位出资的投资者那里能得到什么，同时受限于他们对这是否会令后来的投资者望而却步的估计。

paragraphs.original: But there may not have to be just one valuation. Startups are increasingly raising money on convertible notes, and convertible notes have not valuations but at most valuation caps: caps on what the effective valuation will be when the debt converts to equity (in a later round, or upon acquisition if that happens first).
paragraphs.translated: 但并不一定只有一个估值。初创公司越来越多地通过可转换债券筹集资金，而可转换债券没有估值，最多只有估值上限：即债务转换为股权时（在后续轮融资或被收购时）的有效估值上限。

paragraphs.original: That's an important difference because it means a startup could do multiple notes at once with different caps. This is now starting to happen, and I predict it will become more common.SheepThe reason things are moving this way is that the old way sucked for startups.
paragraphs.translated: 这是一个重要的区别，因为它意味着初创公司可以同时进行多个融资轮次，每个轮次的上限不同。这种情况现在开始出现，我预测它会变得越来越普遍。原因在于旧的方式对初创公司来说很糟糕。

paragraphs.original: Leads could (and did) use a fixed size round as a legitimate-seeming way of saying what all founders hate to hear: I'll invest if other people will. Most investors, unable to judge startups for themselves, rely instead on the opinions of other investors.
paragraphs.translated: 领投人可以（也确实这么做了）利用固定规模的融资轮次作为看似合理的方式来表达所有创始人最不愿听到的话：如果其他人投资，我也会投资。大多数投资者由于无法自行判断初创企业，反而依赖其他投资者的意见。

paragraphs.original: If everyone wants in, they want in too; if not, not. Founders hate this because it's a recipe for deadlock, and delay is the thing a startup can least afford. Most investors know this m.o. is lame, and few say openly that they're doing it.
paragraphs.translated: 如果大家都想参与，他们也想参与；如果大家不想，他们也不想。创始人非常讨厌这种情况，因为它会导致僵局，而初创公司最不能承受的就是拖延。大多数投资者都知道这种做法很糟糕，很少有人会公开承认他们在这样做。

paragraphs.original: But the craftier ones achieve the same result by offering to lead rounds of fixed size and supplying only part of the money. If the startup can't raise the rest, the lead is out too. How could they go ahead with the deal?
paragraphs.translated: 但更狡猾的人通过提出领导固定规模的融资轮并只提供部分资金来达到同样的目的。如果初创公司无法筹集到剩余的资金，领投方也会退出。他们怎么可能继续进行这笔交易呢？

paragraphs.original: The startup would be underfunded!In the future, investors will increasingly be unable to offer investment subject to contingencies like other people investing. Or rather, investors who do that will get last place in line.
paragraphs.translated: 这家初创公司将资金不足！未来，投资者将越来越无法在其他条件（如其他人投资）下提供投资。或者换句话说，这样做的投资者将排在最后。

paragraphs.original: Startups will go to them only to fill up rounds that are mostly subscribed. And since hot startups tend to have rounds that are oversubscribed, being last in line means they'll probably miss the hot deals.
paragraphs.translated: 初创公司将只去找那些已经大部分认购的轮次。而由于热门的初创公司往往会有超额认购的轮次，排在最后意味着他们可能会错过热门的投资机会。

paragraphs.original: Hot deals and successful startups are not identical, but there is a significant correlation. [8] So investors who won't invest unilaterally will have lower returns.Investors will probably find they do better when deprived of this crutch anyway.
paragraphs.translated: 热门交易和成功的初创公司并不完全相同，但两者之间存在显著的相关性。因此，不会单方面投资的投资者将获得较低的回报。投资者可能会发现，即使没有这种依赖，他们反而会表现得更好。

paragraphs.original: Chasing hot deals doesn't make investors choose better; it just makes them feel better about their choices. I've seen feeding frenzies both form and fall apart many times, and as far as I can tell they're mostly random.
paragraphs.translated: 追逐热门交易并不会让投资者做出更好的选择；它只是让投资者对自己的选择感觉更好。我见过许多次这样的狂热场面，无论是形成还是瓦解，据我观察，它们大多都是随机的。

paragraphs.original: [9] If investors can no longer rely on their herd instincts, they'll have to think more about each startup before investing. They may be surprised how well this works.Deadlock wasn't the only disadvantage of letting a lead investor manage an angel round.
paragraphs.translated: [9] 如果投资者不能再依赖他们的从众心理，他们就不得不在投资前更仔细地考虑每个创业公司。他们可能会惊讶于这种方法的效果。让领投投资者管理天使轮融资的劣势不仅仅是僵局。

paragraphs.original: The investors would not infrequently collude to push down the valuation. And rounds took too long to close, because however motivated the lead was to get the round closed, he was not a tenth as motivated as the startup.Increasingly, startups are taking charge of their own angel rounds.
paragraphs.translated: 投资者们时常会串通一气，压低估值。而融资轮次的关闭时间往往过长，因为尽管领投者有很强的意愿完成融资轮次，但他的积极性远不及初创企业。越来越多的初创企业开始自行掌控自己的天使轮融资。

paragraphs.original: Only a few do so far, but I think we can already declare the old way dead, because those few are the best startups. They're the ones in a position to tell investors how the round is going to work. And if the startups you want to invest in do things a certain way, what difference does it make what the others do?TractionIn fact, it may be slightly misleading to say that angel rounds will increasingly take the place of series A rounds.
paragraphs.translated: 目前只有少数这样做，但我认为我们已经可以宣布旧的方式已经死亡，因为这些少数是最好的初创公司。它们是那些能够告诉投资者这一轮融资将如何进行的公司。如果你想要投资的初创公司以某种特定的方式运作，其他公司怎么做又有什么关系呢？ traction 实际上，说天使轮融资将越来越多地取代A轮融资可能略微有些误导。

paragraphs.original: What's really happening is that startup-controlled rounds are taking the place of investor-controlled rounds.This is an instance of a very important meta-trend, one that Y Combinator itself has been based on from the beginning: founders are becoming increasingly powerful relative to investors.
paragraphs.translated: 实际上，初创公司控制的融资轮次正在取代投资者控制的融资轮次。这是一个非常重要的宏观趋势的例证，而 Y Combinator 从一开始就基于这一趋势：创始人相对于投资者的权力正在日益增强。

paragraphs.original: So if you want to predict what the future of venture funding will be like, just ask: how would founders like it to be? One by one, all the things founders dislike about raising money are going to get eliminated.
paragraphs.translated: 所以，如果你想预测风险投资的未来会是什么样子，只需问一问：创始人希望它是什么样的？一项一项地，创始人不喜欢的关于融资的所有事情都将被消除。

paragraphs.original: [10]Using that heuristic, I'll predict a couple more things. One is that investors will increasingly be unable to wait for startups to have "traction" before they put in significant money. It's hard to predict in advance which startups will succeed.
paragraphs.translated: 使用这一经验法则，我还将预测另外几件事。其中之一是，投资者将越来越无法等待初创公司在投入大量资金之前获得“ traction”（ traction 在此指初期的市场认可或用户增长）。要提前预测哪些初创公司会成功是很困难的。

paragraphs.original: So most investors prefer, if they can, to wait till the startup is already succeeding, then jump in quickly with an offer. Startups hate this as well, partly because it tends to create deadlock, and partly because it seems kind of slimy.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，大多数投资者如果可以的话，更愿意等到初创公司已经开始取得成功，然后迅速提出投资。初创公司也很厌恶这一点，部分原因是因为这往往会形成僵局，部分原因是因为这种做法显得有些不地道。

paragraphs.original: If you're a promising startup but don't yet have significant growth, all the investors are your friends in words, but few are in actions. They all say they love you, but they all wait to invest. Then when you start to see growth, they claim they were your friend all along, and are aghast at the thought you'd be so disloyal as to leave them out of your round.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你是一家有潜力的初创公司，但尚未实现显著增长，那么所有的投资者在口头上都是你的朋友，但真正付诸行动的却寥寥无几。他们都说喜欢你，但却都在等待时机投资。而当你开始展现出增长的迹象时，他们又会说自己一直是你的朋友，并对你会如此“不忠”地将他们排除在融资轮之外感到震惊。

paragraphs.original: If founders become more powerful, they'll be able to make investors give them more money upfront.(The worst variant of this behavior is the tranched deal, where the investor makes a small initial investment, with more to follow if the startup does well.
paragraphs.translated: 如果创始人变得更加有影响力，他们就能让投资者提前给他们更多的资金。（这种行为的最糟糕形式是分阶段投资，即投资者先进行一小笔初始投资，如果创业公司表现良好，再追加更多投资。）

paragraphs.original: In effect, this structure gives the investor a free option on the next round, which they'll only take if it's worse for the startup than they could get in the open market. Tranched deals are an abuse.
paragraphs.translated: 实际上，这种结构赋予了投资者在下一轮融资中的一项免费期权，他们只会行使这项权利，如果这一轮融资对初创公司来说比公开市场能获得的条件更差。分期交易是一种滥用。

paragraphs.original: They're increasingly rare, and they're going to get rarer.) [11]Investors don't like trying to predict which startups will succeed, but increasingly they'll have to. Though the way that happens won't necessarily be that the behavior of existing investors will change; it may instead be that they'll be replaced by other investors with different behavior—that investors who understand startups well enough to take on the hard problem of predicting their trajectory will tend to displace suits whose skills lie more in raising money from LPs.SpeedThe other thing founders hate most about fundraising is how long it takes.
paragraphs.translated: 它们越来越稀少，而且将会变得更加稀有。）[11]投资者不喜欢试图预测哪些初创公司会成功，但他们会越来越多地被迫这样做。尽管这种情况的发生方式不一定是现有投资者的行为会发生改变；更可能是他们会被其他行为不同的投资者所取代——那些足够了解初创公司，能够承担起预测其发展轨迹这一艰巨任务的投资者，往往会取代那些更擅长从有限合伙人那里筹集资金的投资者。速度创始人最不喜欢的关于融资的另一件事就是它所花费的时间。

paragraphs.original: So as founders become more powerful, rounds should start to close faster.Fundraising is still terribly distracting for startups. If you're a founder in the middle of raising a round, the round is the top idea in your mind, which means working on the company isn't.
paragraphs.translated: 因此，随着创始人的权力增大，融资轮次应该开始更快地关闭。对于初创企业来说，融资仍然是一个非常分散注意力的事情。如果你是一名正在筹集资金的创始人，融资轮次会成为你心中最重要的事情，这意味着你无法专心经营公司。

paragraphs.original: If a round takes 2 months to close, which is reasonably fast by present standards, that means 2 months during which the company is basically treading water. That's the worst thing a startup could do.So if investors want to get the best deals, the way to do it will be to close faster.
paragraphs.translated: 如果一轮融资需要2个月才能完成，这在当前标准下已经算是相当快的了，但这意味着公司在这2个月里基本上是在停滞不前。这对初创公司来说是最糟糕的事情。因此，如果投资者想要获得最好的投资机会，他们需要加快融资的完成速度。

paragraphs.original: Investors don't need weeks to make up their minds anyway. We decide based on about 10 minutes of reading an application plus 10 minutes of in person interview, and we only regret about 10% of our decisions.
paragraphs.translated: 投资者根本不需要几周的时间来做决定。我们根据大约10分钟阅读申请材料加上10分钟的面对面面试来决定，而我们只对大约10%的决定感到后悔。

paragraphs.original: If we can decide in 20 minutes, surely the next round of investors can decide in a couple days. [12]There are a lot of institutionalized delays in startup funding: the multi-week mating dance with investors; the distinction between termsheets and deals; the fact that each series A has enormously elaborate, custom paperwork.
paragraphs.translated: 如果我们能在20分钟内做出决定，那么下一轮的投资者肯定能在几天内做出决定。[12]在初创企业融资过程中存在许多制度化的延迟：与投资者的多周“求偶舞”；条款书与实际交易之间的区别；每个A轮融资都有极其复杂、定制的文件。

paragraphs.original: Both founders and investors tend to take these for granted. It's the way things have always been. But ultimately the reason these delays exist is that they're to the advantage of investors. More time gives investors more information about a startup's trajectory, and it also tends to make startups more pliable in negotiations, since they're usually short of money.These conventions weren't designed to drag out the funding process, but that's why they're allowed to persist.
paragraphs.translated: 创始者和投资者往往对此习以为常。事情一贯如此。但最终这些拖延存在的原因是它们对投资者有利。更多的时间让投资者能够获得更多关于初创公司发展轨迹的信息，同时也往往使初创公司在谈判中更加容易被操控，因为它们通常资金短缺。这些惯例并不是为了拖延融资过程而设计的，但这就是它们能够持续存在的原因。

paragraphs.original: Slowness is to the advantage of investors, who have in the past been the ones with the most power. But there is no need for rounds to take months or even weeks to close, and once founders realize that, it's going to stop.
paragraphs.translated: 缓慢对投资者有利，过去他们一直是权力最大的一方。但融资轮次没有必要耗时数月甚至数周才能完成，一旦创始人意识到这一点，这种情况就会停止。

paragraphs.original: Not just in angel rounds, but in series A rounds too. The future is simple deals with standard terms, done quickly.One minor abuse that will get corrected in the process is option pools. In a traditional series A round, before the VCs invest they make the company set aside a block of stock for future hires—usually between 10 and 30% of the company.
paragraphs.translated: 不仅在天使轮融资中，而且在A轮融资中也是如此。未来的趋势是快速完成条款简单的标准交易。在这个过程中，期权池这一小问题也将得到纠正。在传统的A轮融资中，风险投资人在投资之前会要求公司预留一部分股票用于未来的招聘，通常占公司总股本的10%到30%。

paragraphs.original: The point is to ensure this dilution is borne by the existing shareholders. The practice isn't dishonest; founders know what's going on. But it makes deals unnecessarily complicated. In effect the valuation is 2 numbers.
paragraphs.translated: 关键是要确保这种稀释由现有股东承担。这种做法并不算不诚实；创始人清楚发生了什么。但这使得交易变得不必要的复杂。实际上，估值变成了两个数字。

paragraphs.original: There's no need to keep doing this. [13]The final thing founders want is to be able to sell some of their own stock in later rounds. This won't be a change, because the practice is now quite common. A lot of investors hated the idea, but the world hasn't exploded as a result, so it will happen more, and more openly.SurpriseI've talked here about a bunch of changes that will be forced on investors as founders become more powerful.
paragraphs.translated: 无需再继续这样做。[13]创始人最终希望能够在后续融资轮中出售自己的一些股份。这不会成为变化，因为这种做法现在已经相当普遍。很多投资者曾经讨厌这个想法，但世界并没有因此而崩溃，所以这种情况会越来越多，而且会更加公开。我还提到，随着创始人的权力增大，投资者将被迫接受一系列变化。

paragraphs.original: Now the good news: investors may actually make more money as a result.A couple days ago an interviewer asked me if founders having more power would be better or worse for the world. I was surprised, because I'd never considered that question.
paragraphs.translated: 现在有个好消息：投资者实际上可能会因此赚更多的钱。几天前，一位采访者问我，创始人拥有更多权力对世界来说是好是坏。我感到惊讶，因为我从未考虑过这个问题。

paragraphs.original: Better or worse, it's happening. But after a second's reflection, the answer seemed obvious. Founders understand their companies better than investors, and it has to be better if the people with more knowledge have more power.One of the mistakes novice pilots make is overcontrolling the aircraft: applying corrections too vigorously, so the aircraft oscillates about the desired configuration instead of approaching it asymptotically.
paragraphs.translated: 好也罢，坏也罢，事情正在发生。但稍作思考后，答案似乎显而易见。创始人比投资者更了解自己的公司，如果知识更多的人拥有更多的权力，情况必须更好。新手飞行员常犯的一个错误是过度控制飞机：修正动作过于猛烈，导致飞机在期望的状态附近振荡，而不是渐近地接近目标状态。

paragraphs.original: It seems probable that investors have till now on average been overcontrolling their portfolio companies. In a lot of startups, the biggest source of stress for the founders is not competitors but investors.
paragraphs.translated: 看来投资者迄今为止在平均意义上一直对他们的投资组合公司管理过度。在许多初创企业中，创始人最大的压力来源不是竞争对手，而是投资者。

paragraphs.original: Certainly it was for us at Viaweb. And this is not a new phenomenon: investors were James Watt's biggest problem too. If having less power prevents investors from overcontrolling startups, it should be better not just for founders but for investors too.Investors may end up with less stock per startup, but startups will probably do better with founders more in control, and there will almost certainly be more of them.
paragraphs.translated: 当然，对我们来说是这样。这并不是一个新现象：詹姆斯·瓦特最大的问题也是投资者。如果权力较小能防止投资者过度控制初创公司，那么这不仅对创始人有利，对投资者也有利。投资者在每个初创公司中的股权可能会减少，但创始人更有掌控权的初创公司可能会表现得更好，而且初创公司的数量肯定会更多。

paragraphs.original: Investors all compete with one another for deals, but they aren't one another's main competitor. Our main competitor is employers. And so far that competitor is crushing us. Only a tiny fraction of people who could start a startup do.
paragraphs.translated: 投资者们都在争夺交易机会，但他们彼此并不是最主要的竞争对手。我们真正的竞争对手是雇主。到目前为止，这个竞争对手正在碾压我们。只有极少数有能力创办初创公司的人真正去做了。

paragraphs.original: Nearly all customers choose the competing product, a job. Why? Well, let's look at the product we're offering. An unbiased review would go something like this: Starting a startup gives you more freedom and the opportunity to make a lot more money than a job, but it's also hard work and at times very stressful.
paragraphs.translated: 几乎所有客户都选择了竞争对手的产品，即工作。为什么？好吧，让我们来看看我们提供的产品。一个公正的评价可能是这样的：创业给你更多的自由和赚更多钱的机会，但这也是一项艰苦的工作，有时会非常有压力。

paragraphs.original: Much of the stress comes from dealing with investors. If reforming the investment process removed that stress, we'd make our product much more attractive. The kind of people who make good startup founders don't mind dealing with technical problems—they enjoy technical problems—but they hate the type of problems investors cause.Investors have no idea that when they maltreat one startup, they're preventing 10 others from happening, but they are.
paragraphs.translated: 很多压力来自于应对投资者。如果改革投资流程能消除这种压力，我们将使我们的产品更具吸引力。那些擅长创业的人并不介意处理技术问题——他们享受解决技术问题的过程——但他们讨厌投资者带来的问题。投资者并不知道，当他们不好好对待一家初创公司时，实际上是在阻止其他十家公司的成立，但事实确实如此。

paragraphs.original: Indirectly, but they are. So when investors stop trying to squeeze a little more out of their existing deals, they'll find they're net ahead, because so many more new deals appear.One of our axioms at Y Combinator is not to think of deal flow as a zero-sum game.
paragraphs.translated: 间接地，但确实如此。因此，当投资者不再试图从现有的交易中榨取更多利益时，他们会发现自己总体上是领先的，因为会有更多的新交易出现。我们在 Y Combinator 的一个公理是不要将交易流视为零和游戏。

paragraphs.original: Our main focus is to encourage more startups to happen, not to win a larger share of the existing stream. We've found this principle very useful, and we think as it spreads outward it will help later stage investors as well."Make something people want" applies to us too.Notes[1] In this essay I'm talking mainly about software startups.
paragraphs.translated: 我们的主要目标是鼓励更多的初创企业涌现，而不是在现有的市场中争取更大的份额。我们发现这一原则非常有用，我们认为随着这一原则的推广，它也将有助于后期投资者。“做人们想要的东西”这一原则同样适用于我们。注[1] 在这篇文章中，我主要谈论的是软件初创企业。

paragraphs.original: These points don't apply to types of startups that are still expensive to start, e.g. in energy or biotech.Even the cheap kinds of startups will generally raise large amounts at some point, when they want to hire a lot of people.
paragraphs.translated: 这些观点并不适用于那些启动成本仍然很高的创业公司类型，例如能源或生物技术领域。即使是启动成本较低的创业公司，在需要招聘大量员工时，通常也会在某个阶段筹集大量资金。

paragraphs.original: What has changed is how much they can get done before that.[2] It's not the distribution of good startups that has a power law dropoff, but the distribution of potentially good startups, which is to say, good deals.
paragraphs.translated: 发生变化的是他们在这之前能完成多少工作。[2] 并不是优质创业公司的分布呈幂律递减，而是潜在优质创业公司的分布，也就是说，好的投资机会。

paragraphs.original: There are lots of potential winners, from which a few actual winners emerge with superlinear certainty.[3] As I was writing this, I asked some founders who'd taken series A rounds from top VC funds whether it was worth it, and they unanimously said yes.The quality of investor is more important than the type of round, though.
paragraphs.translated: 有很多潜在的赢家，其中少数实际赢家会以超线性的概率脱颖而出。在我写这篇文章时，我问了一些从顶级风投基金拿到A轮融资的创始人，他们是否觉得这样做值得，他们一致回答说是的。不过，投资者的质量比融资轮次的类型更重要。

paragraphs.original: I'd take an angel round from good angels over a series A from a mediocre VC.[4] Founders also worry that taking an angel investment from a VC means they'll look bad if the VC declines to participate in the next round.
paragraphs.translated: 我宁愿从好的天使投资人那里获得一轮融资，也不愿从平庸的风险投资人那里获得A轮融资。创始人还担心，如果风险投资人不在下一轮投资中参与，他们可能会因此显得不好。

paragraphs.original: The trend of VC angel investing is so new that it's hard to say how justified this worry is.Another danger, pointed out by Mitch Kapor, is that if VCs are only doing angel deals to generate series A deal flow, then their incentives aren't aligned with the founders'.
paragraphs.translated: 风险投资天使投资的趋势如此新颖，以至于很难说这种担忧是否有根据。 Mitch Kapor 指出的另一个危险是，如果风险投资者只是为了生成 A 轮交易流而进行天使轮投资，那么他们的利益就与创始人不一致。

paragraphs.original: The founders want the valuation of the next round to be high, and the VCs want it to be low. Again, hard to say yet how much of a problem this will be.[5] Josh Kopelman pointed out that another way to be on fewer boards at once is to take board seats for shorter periods.[6] Google was in this respect as so many others the pattern for the future.
paragraphs.translated: 创始人希望下一轮的估值高，而风险投资家则希望估值低。再次，现在还很难说这会成为多大的问题。[5] Josh Kopelman 指出，另一种同时担任较少董事会成员的方法是缩短担任董事会成员的期限。[6] 在这方面，谷歌和其他许多方面一样，成为了未来的典范。

paragraphs.original: It would be great for VCs if the similarity extended to returns. That's probably too much to hope for, but the returns may be somewhat higher, as I explain later.[7] Doing a rolling close doesn't mean the company is always raising money.
paragraphs.translated: 如果相似性也能延伸到回报上，对风险投资家来说就太好了。这可能希望过高，但回报可能会高一些，我在后文中会解释。[7] 采用滚动关闭的方式并不意味着公司一直在募集资金。

paragraphs.original: That would be a distraction. The point of a rolling close is to make fundraising take less time, not more. With a classic fixed sized round, you don't get any money till all the investors agree, and that often creates a situation where they all sit waiting for the others to act.
paragraphs.translated: 那将是一种分散注意力的行为。滚动关闭的目的是让融资过程花费更少的时间，而不是更多。在传统的固定规模融资轮中，你只有等到所有投资者都同意后才能拿到钱，而这通常会导致他们所有人都坐等其他人采取行动。

paragraphs.original: A rolling close usually prevents this. [8] There are two (non-exclusive) causes of hot deals: the quality of the company, and domino effects among investors. The former is obviously a better predictor of success.[9] Some of the randomness is concealed by the fact that investment is a self fulfilling prophecy.[10] The shift in power to founders is exaggerated now because it's a seller's market.
paragraphs.translated: 滚动关闭通常可以防止这种情况。[8] 热门交易有两种（非互斥的）原因：公司的质量以及投资者之间的多米诺效应。前者显然是成功更好的预测指标。[9] 一些随机性被投资是一种自我实现的预言这一事实所掩盖。[10] 由于现在是卖方市场，权力向创始人倾斜的现象被夸大了。

paragraphs.original: On the next downtick it will seem like I overstated the case. But on the next uptick after that, founders will seem more powerful than ever.[11] More generally, it will become less common for the same investor to invest in successive rounds, except when exercising an option to maintain their percentage.
paragraphs.translated: 在下一个下跌时，我的观点可能会显得有些夸大。但在此之后的下一个上涨时，创始人们看起来将比以往任何时候都更加强大。更广泛地说，同一投资者连续多轮投资的情况将变得不那么常见，除非是为了维持其持股比例而行使期权。

paragraphs.original: When the same investor invests in successive rounds, it often means the startup isn't getting market price. They may not care; they may prefer to work with an investor they already know; but as the investment market becomes more efficient, it will become increasingly easy to get market price if they want it.
paragraphs.translated: 当同一位投资者在连续几轮中进行投资时，通常意味着这家初创公司没有获得市场价格。他们可能并不介意；他们可能更愿意与已经熟悉的投资者合作；但随着投资市场的效率提高，如果他们愿意，将越来越容易获得市场价格。

paragraphs.original: Which in turn means the investment community will tend to become more stratified.[12] The two 10 minuteses have 3 weeks between them so founders can get cheap plane tickets, but except for that they could be adjacent.[13] I'm not saying option pools themselves will go away.
paragraphs.translated: 这意味着投资界将趋于更加分层。[12] 这两次十分钟的活动之间相隔三周，这样创始人可以买到便宜的机票，但除此之外，它们可以是连续的。[13] 我并不是说期权池本身会消失。

paragraphs.original: They're an administrative convenience. What will go away is investors requiring them.
